lines.content: Chatty is a simple yet powerful task management chatbot designed to help you organize your tasks efficiently.
It supports adding different types of tasks, marking them as completed, searching for tasks, and more—all
through a command-line interface. This guide will walk you through how to install and use Chatty effectively.
1. **Ensure you have Java 17 or above installed** on your computer.
- **Mac users**: Ensure you have the exact JDK version prescribed [here](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/javaInstallationMac.html).
- Windows & Linux users: Download Java from
or install it using your package manager.
3. **Copy the file** to the folder you want to use as the home folder for your Chatty bot.
- `cd` into the folder where you placed the `chatty.jar` file.
5. **Run the application** using the following command:
6. The GUI should appear in a few seconds similar to the picture below.
7. Type your commands into the text field and press Send to execute them.
For example, typing `help` and pressing Send will display a list of available commands.
**Warning:** All commands are case-sensitive and must be typed in lowercase.
Adds a new task without a deadline.
Adds a task with a specific deadline.
Adds an event with a duration.
Marks a specific task as completed.
Marks a specific task as not completed.
Finds all tasks containing the specified keyword (case-sensitive) in the description.
Displays a list of available commands.
| `todo [task]`                                              | Adds a new task without a deadline.                   |
| `deadline [task] /by [dd/mm/yyyy hhmm]`                    | Adds a task with a specific deadline.                 |
| `event [task] /from [start date/time] /to [end date/time]` | Adds an event with a specific date.                   |
| `mark [task number]`                                       | Marks a specific task as completed.                  |
| `unmark [task number]`                                     | Marks a specific task as not completed.              |
| `help`                                                     | Displays a list of available commands.               |
| `find [keyword]`                                           | Finds all tasks containing the specified keyword.    |
Chatty automatically saves your tasks in a local file. The next time you run Chatty,
your previous tasks will still be available.
If you enter an incorrect command, Chatty will notify you and provide guidance on the correct format.
### Chatty does not start when I run the .jar file.
- Ensure you have Java 17 or later installed.
- Check that you are in the correct directory where chatty.jar is located.
- Try running `java -version` to verify your Java installation.
### Chatty does not save my tasks after restarting.
- Make sure you have write permissions for the folder where chatty.jar is stored.
- The storage file might be corrupted. Try deleting it and running Chatty again.
- Delete the task storage file (chatty.csv) in the home folder where chatty.jar is stored.
#### Found a bug or have an idea for improvement? Report them in [GitHub Issues](https://github.com/Siyan-G/ip/issues).

Chatty is a simple yet powerful task management chatbot designed to help you organize your tasks efficiently.
It supports adding different types of tasks, marking them as completed, searching for tasks, and more—all
through a command-line interface. This guide will walk you through how to install and use Chatty effectively.
1. **Ensure you have Java 17 or above installed** on your computer.
- **Mac users**: Ensure you have the exact JDK version prescribed [here](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/javaInstallationMac.html).
- Windows & Linux users: Download Java from
or install it using your package manager.
3. **Copy the file** to the folder you want to use as the home folder for your Chatty bot.
- `cd` into the folder where you placed the `chatty.jar` file.
5. **Run the application** using the following command:
6. The GUI should appear in a few seconds similar to the picture below.
7. Type your commands into the text field and press Send to execute them.
For example, typing `help` and pressing Send will display a list of available commands.
**Warning:** All commands are case-sensitive and must be typed in lowercase.
Adds a new task without a deadline.
Adds a task with a specific deadline.
Adds an event with a duration.
Marks a specific task as completed.
Marks a specific task as not completed.
Finds all tasks containing the specified keyword (case-sensitive) in the description.
Displays a list of available commands.
| `todo [task]`                                              | Adds a new task without a deadline.                   |
| `deadline [task] /by [dd/mm/yyyy hhmm]`                    | Adds a task with a specific deadline.                 |
| `event [task] /from [start date/time] /to [end date/time]` | Adds an event with a specific date.                   |
| `mark [task number]`                                       | Marks a specific task as completed.                  |
| `unmark [task number]`                                     | Marks a specific task as not completed.              |
| `help`                                                     | Displays a list of available commands.               |
| `find [keyword]`                                           | Finds all tasks containing the specified keyword.    |
Chatty automatically saves your tasks in a local file. The next time you run Chatty,
your previous tasks will still be available.
If you enter an incorrect command, Chatty will notify you and provide guidance on the correct format.
### Chatty does not start when I run the .jar file.
- Ensure you have Java 17 or later installed.
- Check that you are in the correct directory where chatty.jar is located.
- Try running `java -version` to verify your Java installation.
### Chatty does not save my tasks after restarting.
- Make sure you have write permissions for the folder where chatty.jar is stored.
- The storage file might be corrupted. Try deleting it and running Chatty again.
- Delete the task storage file (chatty.csv) in the home folder where chatty.jar is stored.
#### Found a bug or have an idea for improvement? Report them in [GitHub Issues](https://github.com/Siyan-G/ip/issues).
* The {@code Chatty} class serves as the main entry point for the Chatty task management application.
* It initializes the user interface (UI), manages task storage, and interacts with the task list.
* The application runs by continuously accepting user commands, parsing them, and executing the
* corresponding actions until the user chooses to exit.
private TaskList taskList; // List of tasks being managed.
private Storage storage; // Storage for loading and saving tasks.
private Ui ui; // User interface for interacting with the user.
* Constructs a new {@code Chatty} instance, initializing the UI, storage, and task list.
* The task list is loaded from the specified CSV file. If loading fails, an empty task list is initialized.
* @param filePath The file path of the CSV file containing saved tasks.
* Returns the introductory message for the Chatty application.
* This method retrieves a predefined welcome message from the UI to be displayed when the application starts.
* @return A string containing the welcome message.
* Processes a user command and returns the appropriate response.
* This method parses the input command, executes the corresponding action,
* and returns the response message. If an error occurs, an error message is returned instead.
* @param input The user command as a string.
* @return The response message after executing the command.
* @throws ChattyException If the command results in an error.
public String getResponse(String input) throws ChattyException {
* Represents a dialog box in the Chatty application.
* A dialog box consists of an {@code ImageView} to display the speaker's avatar
* and a {@code Label} containing the speaker's text. This class provides methods
* to create user and Chatty response dialog boxes with appropriate formatting.
* Constructs a {@code DialogBox} with the specified text and image.
* This constructor loads the corresponding FXML file and initializes the dialog text and image.
* @param text The text message to be displayed.
* @param img  The image representing the speaker.
* Flips the dialog box so that the {@code ImageView} appears on the left
* and the text appears on the right.
* Creates a dialog box representing user input.
* @param text The text message from the user.
* @param img  The image representing the user.
* @return A {@code DialogBox} instance for the user's message.
public static DialogBox getUserDialog(String text, Image img) {
* Creates a dialog box representing Chatty's response.
* This method also flips the dialog box layout so that Chatty's response appears
* @param text The text message from Chatty.
* @return A {@code DialogBox} instance for Chatty's message.
public static DialogBox getChattyDialog(String text, Image img) {
* The {@code Launcher} class serves as an entry point to start the Chatty application.
* This class acts as a workaround for JavaFX classpath issues that may arise when launching
* the application directly from a JAR file. It delegates the execution to {@link Main}.
* @param args Command-line arguments passed to the application.
* The {@code Main} class serves as the entry point for launching the Chatty application with a GUI.
* This class extends {@link Application} to initialize and display the JavaFX user interface.
* It loads the FXML layout, sets up the main application window, and connects the GUI to the
* {@link Chatty} backend for handling user interactions.
private final Chatty chatty = new Chatty("./data/tasks.csv");
* Starts the JavaFX application by setting up the main window.
* This method loads the {@code MainWindow.fxml} layout, initializes the scene,
* and injects the {@link Chatty} instance into the controller.
* @param stage The primary stage for the application.
* The {@code MainWindow} class serves as the controller for the Chatty application's main GUI.
* It manages user interactions by handling text input, displaying responses, and maintaining
* the chat layout. This class initializes the JavaFX components and binds UI elements dynamically.
private static final String INTRO_MSG = "Hello Master! I'm Chatty, your ever-ready personal assistant."
+ " How can I help you today?"
+ "\nType \"help\" and click \"Send\" to view the list of commands available";
* This method ensures the scroll pane automatically scrolls down as new messages
* are added to the dialog container.
* Injects the {@link Chatty} instance into the controller.
* @param chatty The Chatty instance that handles user commands.
* Handles user input by creating and displaying dialog boxes.
* This method retrieves user input, processes it using {@link Chatty#getResponse(String)},
* and displays both the user input and Chatty's response in the dialog container.
* The text field is cleared after processing.
* @throws ChattyException If an error occurs while processing the user input.
* Represents an abstract command that can be executed.
* Each command may modify the task list, interact with the user, and update storage.
* The command does not terminate the program.
* Constructs a command with the specified exit status.
* @param isExit {@code true} if the command should terminate the program, {@code false} otherwise.
* Returns whether this command is an exit command.
* @return {@code true} if the command terminates the program, {@code false} otherwise.
* Executes the command with the given task list, user interface, and storage.
* @param tasks   The task list to be modified.
* @param ui      The user interface to interact with the user.
* @param storage The storage to save or load data.
* @throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException If the specified task is not found.
public abstract String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException;
* Represents a command to add a deadline to a list of tasks.
* This class is used to create a Deadline object with a description and a deadline time,
* and then add it to the TaskList. It also saves the updated list of tasks to storage
* and provides feedback to the user through the Ui component.
* Constructs a DeadlineCommand with a specified description and deadline.
* @param description A brief description of the deadline task.
* @param deadline The date and time when the deadline is set.
* Executes the command to add the deadline task to the task list and save it to storage.
* Provides feedback to the user on the result of the operation.
* @param tasks The TaskList where the Deadline will be added.
* @param ui The UI to communicate feedback to the user.
* @param storage The storage responsible for saving tasks.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
return ui.getMessage(String.format("New deadline: %s, added to the list\nNow you have %d tasks in the list.",
* Represents a command to delete a task from the task list.
* This class allows the deletion of a task from the TaskList based on the specified index.
* It also updates the storage by saving the modified list of tasks and provides feedback
* to the user through the Ui component.
* Constructs a DeleteCommand with a specified task index.
* @param taskIndex The index of the task to be deleted from the task list.
* Executes the command to delete the specified task from the task list and save the updated list to storage.
* Provides feedback to the user on the result of the operation.
* @param tasks The TaskList from which the task will be deleted.
* @param ui The UI to communicate feedback to the user.
* @param storage The storage responsible for saving tasks.
* @throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException If the task with the given index is not found in the task list.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException {
return ui.getMessage(String.format("Yikes! Task %d: %s, has been deleted.", taskIndex, deletedTask));
* Represents a command to add a new event to the task list.
* This class is used to create an Event object with a description, start time, and end time,
* and then add it to the TaskList. It also saves the updated task list to storage and
* provides feedback to the user through the Ui component.
* Constructs an EventCommand with a specified event description, start time, and end time.
* @param eventDescription A brief description of the event.
* @param startTime The starting time of the event, represented as a String.
* @param endTime The ending time of the event, represented as a String.
public EventCommand(String eventDescription, String startTime, String endTime) {
* Executes the command to add the new event to the task list and save it to storage.
* Provides feedback to the user on the result of the operation.
* @param tasks The TaskList to which the new event will be added.
* @param ui The UI to communicate feedback to the user.
* @param storage The storage responsible for saving tasks.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
Event newEvent = new Event(eventDescription, startTime, endTime);
return ui.getMessage(String.format("New event: %s, has added to the list.\nNow you have %d tasks.",
* Represents a command to exit the application.
* This class is used to terminate the application by sending an exit message
* through the Ui component. It does not modify the task list or storage.
* Constructs an ExitCommand that signals the termination of the application.
* Executes the command to exit the application by sending an exit message to the user.
* @param tasks The TaskList, which is not modified in this command.
* @param ui The UI to communicate the exit message to the user.
* @param storage The storage, which is not modified in this command.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
* Represents a command that allows the user to find tasks based on a keyword.
* The {@link FindCommand} class is responsible for searching the task list for tasks containing the specified keyword.
* If no tasks are found, a message is displayed indicating that no matching tasks were found. Otherwise, a list of
* tasks that match the keyword is shown to the user.
* Constructs a {@link FindCommand} with the specified keyword.
* @param keyword The keyword to search for in the task descriptions.
* Executes the find command to search for tasks containing the specified keyword.
* If no tasks are found with the keyword, a message is sent to the user indicating that no tasks were found.
* If tasks are found, a message is sent to the user with the number of matching tasks and their details.
* @param tasks   The list of tasks to search through.
* @param ui      The user interface to communicate results to the user.
* @param storage The storage used to save or load tasks (not used in this command, but included for consistency).
* @throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException If an error occurs while searching for tasks (e.g., invalid task access).
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException {
return ui.getMessage("No task found with keyword " + keyword);
return ui.getMessage(String.format("Woohoo! I found %d tasks with keyword: %s\n%s:",
* Represents a command that provides help information to the user.
* Executes the HelpCommand to display a list of available commands to the user.
* @param tasks   The task list (not used in this command but required by the method signature).
* @param ui      The user interface to interact with the user.
* @param storage The storage system (not used in this command but required by the method signature).
* @return A string containing the help message.
* @throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException If an error occurs while executing the command.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException {
* Represents a command to list all tasks in the task list.
* This class is used to retrieve all tasks from the TaskList and display them to the user.
* It converts the task list into a string representation and sends it to the user through the Ui component.
* Executes the command to display all tasks in the task list.
* The list of tasks is converted to a string and sent as a message to the user.
* @param tasks The TaskList containing the tasks to be displayed.
* @param ui The UI to communicate the list of tasks to the user.
* @param storage The storage, which is not modified in this command.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
return ui.getMessage(String.format("You currently have %d tasks in the list\n%s.",
* Represents a command to mark a task as completed.
* This class is used to mark a specific task in the TaskList as completed based on the provided task ID.
* It also saves the updated task list to storage and provides feedback to the user through the Ui component.
* Constructs a MarkCommand with a specified task ID to mark the corresponding task as completed.
* @param taskId The ID of the task to be marked as completed.
* Executes the command to mark the specified task as completed and save the updated task list to storage.
* Provides feedback to the user on the result of the operation.
* @param tasks The TaskList where the task will be marked as completed.
* @param ui The UI to communicate feedback to the user.
* @param storage The storage responsible for saving tasks.
* @throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException If the task with the given ID is not found in the task list.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException {
return ui.getMessage(String.format("YAY!!! task %d: %s, is completed.", taskId, markedTask));
* Represents a command to add a new "To-Do" task to the task list.
* This class is used to create a Todo task with a description and add it to the TaskList.
* It also saves the updated task list to storage and provides feedback to the user through the Ui component.
* Constructs a TodoCommand with a specified description for the new To-Do task.
* @param description A brief description of the To-Do task to be added.
* Executes the command to add the new To-Do task to the task list and save the updated list to storage.
* Provides feedback to the user on the result of the operation.
* @param tasks The TaskList to which the new To-Do task will be added.
* @param ui The UI to communicate feedback to the user.
* @param storage The storage responsible for saving tasks.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
return ui.getMessage(String.format("New todo: %s, added to list.\nYou now have %d tasks tracked.",
* Represents a command to unmark a task as incomplete.
* This class is used to unmark a specific task in the TaskList as incomplete based on the provided task ID.
* It also saves the updated task list to storage and provides feedback to the user through the Ui component.
* Constructs an UnmarkCommand with a specified task ID to unmark the corresponding task as incomplete.
* @param taskId The ID of the task to be unmarked as incomplete.
* Executes the command to unmark the specified task as incomplete and save the updated task list to storage.
* Provides feedback to the user on the result of the operation.
* @param tasks The TaskList where the task will be unmarked as incomplete.
* @param ui The UI to communicate feedback to the user.
* @param storage The storage responsible for saving tasks.
* @throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException If the task with the given ID is not found in the task list.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws ChattyTaskNotFoundException {
return ui.getMessage(String.format("Uh oh!! task %d: %s, is incomplete.", taskId, unmarkedTask));
* The Parser class is responsible for parsing user input commands and returning the corresponding Command object.
* This class processes a given string command, identifies the type of command, and constructs the appropriate Command
* object. It also validates the format of the user input and throws exceptions for invalid inputs. Supported commands
* include tasks management (such as adding, deleting, marking, and unmarking tasks), as well as event and deadline
* Parses the given command and returns the corresponding Command object.
* @param command The user input command string to be parsed.
* @return The appropriate Command object based on the user input.
* @throws ChattyInvalidCommandException If the command format is incorrect or unsupported.
* @param command The user input command string.
* @throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException If the command format is incorrect.
private static Command parseFindCommand(String command) throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException {
* @param command The user input command string.
private static Command parseDeleteCommand(String command) throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException {
* @param command The user input command string.
* @throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException If the command format is incorrect.
private static Command parseMarkCommand(String command) throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException {
* @param command The user input command string.
* @throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException If the command format is incorrect.
private static Command parseUnmarkCommand(String command) throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException {
* @param command The user input command string.
* @throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException If no description is provided.
private static Command parseTodoCommand(String command) throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException {
* @param command The user input command string.
* @throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException If the event format is incorrect.
private static Command parseEventCommand(String command) throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException {
* @param command The user input command string.
* @throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException If the deadline format is incorrect.
private static Command parseDeadlineCommand(String command) throws ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException {
* The Storage class handles loading and saving tasks to/from a CSV file.
* This class is responsible for managing task persistence by interacting with a specified file for storage.
* It provides methods to load tasks from an existing CSV file or create a new task list if the file is not found,
* and to save the current task list back into the file.
* Constructs a Storage object with a specified file path for task storage.
* @param filePath The path to the file where tasks will be loaded from or saved to.
* Loads tasks from the specified CSV file into a TaskList object.
* If the file does not exist, a new TaskList is returned.
* Each line in the CSV file is parsed to determine the type of task (Todo, Deadline, Event),
* and appropriate task objects are created and added to the TaskList.
* @return A TaskList object containing all tasks loaded from the CSV file.
System.out.println("No existing tasks found. Creating a new local csv for storage");
* Saves the current TaskList into a CSV file.
* This method converts each task in the TaskList into its CSV representation and writes it to the specified file.
* If the parent directories of the file path do not exist, they are created.
* @param tasks The TaskList object containing the tasks to be saved.
* Represents a custom exception in the chatty application.
* This exception class is used to handle general errors in the chatty application.
* It extends the {@link Exception} class and provides a custom string representation
* Returns a custom string representation of the exception.
* The default message "Oopsies!" is returned when this exception is thrown.
* @return A string representing the exception message.
* Represents an exception that is thrown when an invalid input is detected for a chatty command.
* This exception extends the {@link ChattyException} class and is used to indicate that an invalid input
* was passed for a specific command in the chatty application. It provides details about the command that
* Constructs a new ChattyInvalidInputException with the specified command.
* @param command The command that caused the invalid input error.
* Returns a detailed message describing the invalid input error.
* The message includes the command that caused the exception.
* @return A string message that indicates the invalid input for the command.
return String.format("Yikes, I am not supported with this command: %s", command);
* Returns a custom string representation of the exception.
* The string representation includes the message with the command that caused the exception.
* @return A string representing the exception message.
return String.format("Yikes, I supported with this command: %s", command);
* Represents an exception that is thrown when an invalid argument is detected for a chatty command.
* This exception extends the {@link ChattyException} class and is used to indicate that an invalid argument
* was passed for a specific command in the chatty application. It provides details about the command type
* that caused the error, such as the correct format and an example of valid usage.
* Enum representing different command types in the chatty application.
* Each command type includes the correct format of the command and an example usage of the command.
// Static block to initialize the enum constants with their default values
* Returns the correct format for the command type.
* @return The correct format string for the command.
* Returns an example usage of the command type.
* @return The example usage string for the command.
* Constructs a new {@code ChattyInvalidCommandFormatException} with the specified command type.
* This constructor is used to create an exception with information about the command that caused
* @param commandType The type of the command that caused the invalid argument error.
* Returns a detailed message describing the invalid argument error.
* The message includes the command type that caused the exception, the correct format for the command,
* and an example usage of the command.
* @return A string message that indicates the invalid command argument, with the correct format and example.
return String.format("Oopsies! Command format for \"%s\" is incorrect.\nCorrect format: %s.\nExample: %s",
* Returns a custom string representation of the exception.
* This string representation includes the detailed message with the command type that caused the exception.
* @return A string representing the exception message.
* Represents an exception that is thrown when a task could not be found in the chatty application.
* This exception extends the {@link ChattyException} class and is used to indicate that a specific task
* could not be found based on its task ID. It provides details about the task ID that caused the error.
* Constructs a new ChattyTaskNotFoundException with the specified task ID.
* @param taskId The ID of the task that could not be found.
* Returns a detailed message describing the error when a task is not found.
* The message includes the task ID that could not be located.
* @return A string message that indicates the task could not be found.
return String.format("Sorry! task %d could not be found", taskId);
* Returns a custom string representation of the exception.
* The string representation includes the message with the task ID that caused the exception.
* @return A string representing the exception message.
return String.format("Sorry! task %d could not be found", taskId);
* Represents a deadline task in the chatty application.
* This class extends the {@link Task} class and includes a specific deadline time for the task.
* It provides functionality to manage and format deadline tasks, including serialization and deserialization.
* Constructs a new Deadline task with a specified name and deadline.
* @param name     The name or description of the deadline task.
* @param deadline The deadline date and time for the task.
* Constructs a new Deadline task with a specified name, completion status, and deadline.
* @param completed Indicates whether the task is completed.
* @param name      The name or description of the deadline task.
* @param deadline  The deadline date and time for the task.
public Deadline(boolean completed, String name, LocalDateTime deadline) {
* Creates a Deadline task from a CSV string representation.
* The expected CSV format is: "D,[completed status],[task name],[deadline in ISO format]".
* @param line The CSV string representing the deadline task.
* @return A new {@link Deadline} object created from the CSV data.
* @throws IllegalArgumentException If the CSV format is incorrect.
public static Deadline fromCsv(String line) throws IllegalArgumentException {
* Returns a CSV string representation of the deadline task.
* The format is: "D,[completed status],[task name],[deadline in ISO format]".
* @return A CSV string representing the deadline task.
* Returns a string representation of the deadline task.
* The format is: "[D] [task status] [task name] (by: [formatted deadline])".
* @return A string representing the deadline task, including its status and deadline.
DateTimeFormatter formatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy HHmm");
* Represents an event task in the chatty application.
* This class extends the {@link Task} class and includes a start and end time for the event.
* It provides functionality to manage and format event tasks, including serialization and deserialization.
* Constructs a new Event task with a specified name, start time, and end time.
* @param name  The name or description of the event.
* @param start The start time of the event in string format.
* @param end   The end time of the event in string format.
public Event(String name, String start, String end) {
